doc.after: Zerbe's proposal led to the appointment of a committee to transmit the proposal to Congress and urge its adoption.[6] According to numismatic historian Walter Breen, "Apparently, this was the first time that a coin collector ever wielded enough political clout to influence not only the Bureau of the Mint, but Congress as well."[8] The committee included noted coin collector and Congressman William A. Ashbrook (DemocratâOhio), who had chaired the House Committee on Coinage, Weights, and Measures until the Republicans gained control following the 1918 elections.[8]
